{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12632,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Adolphia californica, commonly known as California prickbush, is drought-tolerant and prefers infrequent watering. During the growing season, water deeply but allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has good drainage. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly or stop watering entirely, depending on rainfall in the area. The plant is adapted to dry conditions and can survive on minimal water once established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Adolphia californica thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth. It is well adapted to bright, arid environments and can withstand high temperatures with sufficient sun exposure. Plant it in a location where it won't be shaded by larger shrubs or trees. If grown in partial shade, the plant may not flower profusely and could become leggy. Full sunlight ensures the plant's best health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Adolphia californica during its dormant season, usually late winter, to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches, and thin out any overly crowded stems to increase air circulation. Be cautious of the thorns when pruning. Minimal pruning is typically needed unless the shrub is being shaped for a specific landscape effect. Regular pruning helps in maintaining the desired size, especially if it's used in a garden or as an ornamental plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California adolphia","description":"Adolphia californica, known by the common names California adolphia, California prickbush, and spineshrub, is a species of flowering shrub in the buckthorn family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["California adolphia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Adolphia californica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13234,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leptosiphon ciliatus, commonly known as Whiskerbrush, prefers moderate watering. This plant is somewhat drought-tolerant once established, so it is essential to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, especially in dry climates, water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not saturated. In rainy seasons or humid environments, natural rainfall may be sufficient, and less frequent watering is necessary. Always ensure good drainage to keep the roots healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leptosiphon ciliatus thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. For optimal flowering, providing at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day is beneficial. However, in extremely hot or dry climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent stress and preserve moisture. While it can tolerate a variety of light conditions, insufficient sunlight may result in reduced blooming and leggy growth. If planted in a shaded area, ensure it receives some dappled or indirect light to keep the plant healthy and vigorous. Adjust placement if flowering or growth declines."},{"type":"pruning","description":"When it comes to pruning Leptosiphon ciliatus, minimal pruning is generally required. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can help extend the blooming period by encouraging the plant to produce more flowers. This can be done by pinching or snipping off the faded flowers back to a set of leaves or the stem. If the plant becomes leggy or starts to show signs of disease, cut back the affected growth to promote healthier and bushier foliage. Pruning should ideally be done in early spring or after the blooming period has ended to maintain a neat appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Whiskerbrush","description":"Leptosiphon ciliatus (syn. Linanthus ciliatus) is a species of flowering plant in the phlox family known by the common name whiskerbrush.","family":null,"flower_color":"Multiple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western North America","California"],"other_name":["Whiskerbrush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Leptosiphon ciliatus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12730,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asplenium viride, commonly known as the green spleenwort, prefers to grow in consistently moist conditions. It is crucial to maintain a steady watering schedule, ensuring the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. During active growth periods, typically spring through fall, check the moisture level regularly and water more frequently. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering but never allow the soil to dry out completely. Using lukewarm water can help prevent shocking the roots, and always ensure good drainage to avoid root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asplenium viride thrives in moderate to low light conditions, mimicking its natural habitat of shaded forest environments. It's best kept out of direct sunlight, which can scorch the delicate fronds. A spot with bright, indirect light or a north-facing window is ideal. If growing indoors, consider moving it a bit further from bright windows during peak sunlight hours or use sheer curtains to diffuse the light. Artificial grow lights can also support its light needs if natural lighting is insufficient. Aim for a balance to ensure vibrant growth without sun damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asplenium viride involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy new growth. Regularly inspect the plant and snip off any brown or yellowed leaves close to the base using sharp, clean scissors. This fern doesn't require heavy pruning; mostly it involves tidying up the plant and maintaining its appearance. Avoid cutting healthy green fronds, as this can stress the plant. After pruning, monitor the plant for new growth, which should be robust and lush, contributing to its overall airy appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"green spleenwort","description":"Asplenium viride is known as the green spleenwort because of its green stipes and rachides. This feature easily distinguishes this species from the very similar-looking maidenhair spleenwort, Asplenium trichomanes.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["green spleenwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Asplenium viride"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13727,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ulmus minor, commonly known as the field elm, requires moderate watering, particularly during its first few years to establish a strong root system. Aim to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged; overwatering can be detrimental, leading to root rot. In periods of drought or particularly hot seasons, increase watering frequency to ensure the tree remains healthy. Once established, Ulmus minor is relatively drought-tolerant. During colder months, reduce watering, allowing the natural rainfall to take over unless there are extended dry spells. Always ensure adequate drainage to prevent water accumulation around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ulmus minor thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This level of sunlight exposure helps the tree develop a strong structure and dense foliage. While it can tolerate partial shade, the tree may not reach its full potential in terms of size and health. In less sunny areas, be vigilant for signs of decreased vigor, such as slower growth or reduced leaf production, which might necessitate repositioning the tree to a sunnier spot. Full sun exposure also helps minimize the risk of fungal diseases that flourish in shady, damp environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Ulmus minor should be undertaken in late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant, before new growth begins. The primary goal is to maintain its shape, remove any dead or diseased wood, and promote healthy, structural growth. Remove any inward-growing branches to improve air circulation throughout the canopy. Regular thinning of dense areas will help reduce the risk of disease. It is advisable to avoid heavy pruning during the active growing season as it can stress the tree. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts that heal quickly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Field Elm","description":"Ulmus minor Mill., the field elm, is by far the most polymorphic of the European species, although its taxonomy remains a matter of contention. Its natural range is predominantly south European, extending to Asia Minor and Iran; its northern outposts are the Baltic islands of Öland and Gotland, although it may have been introduced here by man. The tree's typical habitat is low-lying forest along the main rivers, growing in association with oak and ash, where...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Field Elm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Elm Leaf Beetle","Dutch Elm Disease","Gall mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Ulmus minor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It requires minimal watering once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Ensure the plant has good drainage to prevent root rot. During prolonged dry spells, additional occasional watering may be needed. In regions with rainfall, natural precipitation might suffice. Avoid overwatering, especially in cooler months when the plant is dormant, as this can lead to fungal diseases and other moisture-related issues. "},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Peritoma lutea thrives in full sun, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This exposure ensures vigorous growth and abundant flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, the flowering might be reduced, and the plant may become leggy. They are well suited for sunny borders or open plains where they receive unobstructed sun. In regions with extreme heat, providing light afternoon shade can protect the foliage from scorching without compromising too much on flowering. Proper sunlight exposure also reduces the risk of disease by ensuring good air circulation around the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Peritoma lutea in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain plant health and appearance. Cutting back some older growth can encourage bushiness and new flowering. Regular pruning of spent flower stalks promotes further blooming and prevents self-seeding if you want to control its spread. Wear gloves when pruning since the plant may have slight spiny parts. Avoid heavy pruning during late fall or winter to protect the plant from potential stress or damage during colder months. Maintenance pruning can help sustain a tidy and healthy appearance throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yellow beeplant","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["yellow beeplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Peritoma lutea"],"soil":["Loamy","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12431,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hieracium venosum, commonly known as the rattlesnake weed, prefers moderate watering. It thrives in well-drained soil and is relatively drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Overwatering can be detrimental, so it's important to ensure that the plant is never sitting in waterlogged conditions. During hotter months, you might need to increase watering slightly, but always check the soil moisture first. A general guideline is to water once every week or two, depending on the environmental conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hieracium venosum thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. It can tolerate a range of light conditions but performs best in areas where it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. The plant's vibrant foliage and flowers are most pronounced when it gets ample sunlight, although it can adapt to slightly lower light conditions. Ensure it's placed in a spot that meets these requirements to enjoy its attractive appearance and optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hieracium venosum is fairly straightforward and primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth. This can be done at any time of the year, as needed. Additionally, spent flowers should be deadheaded to prevent unwanted self-seeding and to encourage further blooming. Pruning can also help in managing the plant's spread, as it can multiply through its roots. Use clean, sharp scissors or secateurs for cutting to avoid any damage or disease spread, and aim to maintain the plant’s natural form and structure while pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"rattlesnakeweed","description":"Hieracium venosum (Robin’s plantain, rattlesnakeweed, or rattlesnake hawkweed) is a species of hawkweeds in the dandelion tribe within the sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13131,"attracts":["Dragonflies","Ducks"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Glyceria striata, commonly known as fowl mannagrass, thrives in consistently moist soil, making adequate watering crucial for its growth. This plant prefers soil that is damp—almost soggy conditions are ideal, as it often grows in marshes or wet meadows in the wild. Ensure that the soil remains moist but not waterlogged, as stagnant water can lead to root rot. Regular watering, especially during dry spells, will support healthy growth. Use mulch to help retain soil moisture, and consider planting near water features if possible to maintain natural humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Glyceria striata thrives under partial to full shade conditions. While it can tolerate some sun, too much direct sunlight can stress the plant and lead to wilting, especially during the hottest parts of the day. Ideally, provide dappled sunlight or an area in the garden where the plant has protection from intense sun, such as under trees or in areas with filtered light. This species can adapt to various light conditions, but shaded environments similar to its natural wetland habitat promote the healthiest growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Glyceria striata is typically minimal as it is a low-maintenance grass. However, you can tidy up your plant by trimming dead or damaged blades with scissors or garden shears at any time of the year to maintain a neat appearance. During late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, is an ideal time to cut back the previous year's foliage to allow fresh growth to establish. Regularly removing weeds around the plant and clearing any debris can enhance air circulation and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fowl Mannagrass","description":"Glyceria striata is a species of mannagrass which is known by the common names fowl mannagrass and ridged glyceria. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13628,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sibbaldia procumbens prefers moderately moist soil but can tolerate short periods of dryness due to its hardy nature. It is important not to over-water this plant as its roots could rot. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry, and ensure good drainage to prevent standing water. In its native alpine environment, Sibbaldia procumbens benefits from regular rainfall, so mimicking this with consistent watering during dry spells ensures optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sibbaldia procumbens thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, providing this plant with about 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day will ensure robust growth, though it can tolerate shadier spots if needed. In hotter climates, it might benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent the leaves from scorching. Being an alpine plant, it is accustomed to sunny environments, so ample sunlight will help simulate these natural conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sibbaldia procumbens is generally minimal due to its low-growing and spreading nature. However, you can trim back any dead or damaged foliage, particularly after winter or if any leaves become diseased. Pruning can be done in early spring to encourage fresh growth and to maintain the plant’s shape within its habitat. This helps to keep the garden tidy and can also promote the healthy development of the plant’s runners."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"creeping sibbaldia","description":"Sibbaldia procumbens is a species of flowering plant in the rose family known by the common name creeping sibbaldia. It has a circumpolar distribution; it can be found throughout the northern latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere from Arctic regions into higher-elevation temperate areas. This process can be done at any time of the year, but it is typically more common in spring before the growing season begins. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot, as this plant is susceptible to overwatering. During its growing season in spring and summer, water the plant every 2-3 weeks, depending on the indoor climate. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering to once a month or less. Always use a free-draining potting mix and ensure the pot has drainage holes to avoid water accumulation, which can damage the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula ovata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight and can also tolerate direct sunlight for a few hours a day, preferably during the morning or late afternoon when the sun is less intense. Too little light can cause the plant to become leggy, while too much direct afternoon sun might scorch its leaves. A south or west-facing window is ideal, but be cautious during the peak summer months when sunlight is strongest. If growing indoors with limited natural light, consider using a grow light to provide adequate illumination. Rotate the plant occasionally to ensure even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula ovata helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. It is best to prune during the plant's active growing season in spring or early summer. Remove any dead or shriveled leaves by gently plucking them. Trim back leggy stems to encourage a bushier appearance, making cuts just above a leaf node for best results. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. Pruning also helps to remove any pest-damaged parts and promotes the development of new branches and flowers."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"jade plant","description":"Crassula ovata, commonly known as jade plant, friendship tree, lucky plant, or money tree, is a succulent plant with small pink or white flowers. It is native to South Africa and Mozambique, and is common as a houseplant worldwide. Much of its popularity stems from the low levels of care needed; the jade plant requires little water and can survive in most indoor conditions. It is sometimes referred to as the money tree; however, Pachira aquatica...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["jade plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Leaf cutting","Stem cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Crassula ovata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure it grows in high humidity conditions, as it thrives in moist environments. You don't need to water this fungus directly; instead, maintain the surrounding environment's moisture by misting the air around its growth area. This helps mimic its natural habitat and provides the necessary moisture for its development and reproduction cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parasola plicatilis thrives in lightly shaded conditions typically provided by the canopy in forests, as direct sunlight can cause them to dry out quickly. Replicating these natural settings will encourage their proper growth cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a type of mushroom, Parasola plicatilis does not require pruning. This species is ephemeral, meaning it has a short life cycle, typically emerging after rain and decomposing within a day or two. There is no pruning process needed for mushrooms since they do not have branches or leaves. Water it regularly to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during dry spells or in well-drained areas. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, which can occur if the roots sit in standing water for extended periods. Regular pruning helps to maintain shape, remove dead or damaged wood, and promote healthy growth. Cut back long or excessive growth to encourage bushiness. Removing spent flowers can encourage further blooming, although this species tends to flower in a more natural, less controlled manner compared to cultivated roses. Proper sterilization of pruning tools is crucial to prevent the spread of diseases. Keep in mind that this species can tolerate more irregular pruning due to its natural habitat."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swamp rose","description":"Rosa palustris, the swamp rose, is a shrub in the rose family native to much of eastern North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13132,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gossypium hirsutum, commonly known as upland cotton, requires a balanced watering approach. It is essential to maintain consistent moisture, especially during germination and the flowering stage, to avoid stress that could lead to reduced yields. Ideally, water the plant deeply once or twice a week, depending on the climate and soil drainage capabilities. Ensure that the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During cooler months, reduce watering when the plant is dormant. Soil should be allowed to dry slightly between waterings to ensure oxygen reaches the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gossypium hirsutum thrives best with full sunlight exposure. For optimum growth, ensure the plants receive at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight daily. Ideal planting conditions involve choosing a site that is not shaded by buildings, trees, or other plants. Adequate sunlight is crucial for the cotton plant's photosynthesis process, promoting vigorous growth, blooming, and boll development. However, if you're in an excessively hot climate, provide some protection from scorching midday sun to prevent sunburn. Using reflective mulches can help to maximize light absorption and improve growth performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning cotton plants is not traditionally necessary; however, some practices can benefit their growth, particularly in a home garden setting. Light pruning involves removing any dead or diseased leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth and to allow better air circulation, reducing the risk of pests and diseases. Prune around early spring to shape the plant and remove any foliage that hampers sunlight penetration. After harvesting, prune back the cotton plant to reduce its size and encourage a robust structure for the next growing season. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Upland Cotton","description":"Gossypium hirsutum, also known as upland cotton or Mexican cotton, is the most widely planted species of cotton in the world. Globally, about 90% of all cotton production is of cultivars derived from this species. In the United States, the world's largest exporter of cotton, it constitutes approximately 95% of all cotton production. It is native to Mexico, the West Indies, northern South America, Central America and possibly tropical Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","Mexico","South America"],"other_name":["Upland Cotton"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot","Bollworm","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Gossypium hirsutum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14021,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rubus phoenicolasius, commonly known as wineberry, requires moderate watering. It is important to maintain consistently moist soil, especially during the growing season in spring and summer. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. During dry periods, especially in sandy soils, regular watering may be necessary to keep the plant healthy. However, do not allow the soil to become too soggy. Water the plant at the base to minimize wetting the foliage, which can reduce the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus phoenicolasius thrives best in full sunlight conditions. Providing the plant with at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day ensures optimal growth and fruit production. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can lead to reduced fruit yield and may make the plant more susceptible to diseases due to increased humidity and decreased air circulation. If you are planting wineberries in a shaded area, try to find a spot where they can receive morning sunlight as it is less intense and can help dry off morning dew, reducing the chance of fungal problems."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus phoenicolasius is essential to maintain its shape, encourage healthy growth, and improve fruit production. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased canes, and thin out overcrowded canes to allow better air circulation. Too much direct afternoon sun can scorch the leaves, while insufficient light may cause the plant to become leggy as it stretches towards the light source. If grown indoors, supplement with fluorescent lights if natural light is limited. Outdoors, position the plant in a shaded location with dappled sunlight. Ensure gradual adaptation if moving the plant to brighter conditions to prevent sunburn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula tetragona is essential for managing size and encouraging bushier growth. Prune in the spring or summer when the plant is actively growing. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to trim back any leggy or overly elongated stems. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased leaves to maintain plant health. Pinch back branch tips to promote a compact, bushy appearance. Pruning not only enhances the plant’s aesthetic but also improves air circulation around the leaves and stems, reducing the risk of fungal issues. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12335,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Iris foetidissima is relatively drought-tolerant once established, thanks to its rhizomatous root system which retains moisture effectively. Water the plant moderately during its active growing season in spring and summer. Ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged. During the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly to allow the plant to rest, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. It's important to ensure the soil has good drainage, which helps prevent water accumulation and potential root issues. During particularly dry spells, occasional deep watering might be necessary to maintain its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris foetidissima prefers a location with partial shade to full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive at least a few hours of sunlight per day, particularly in the morning or late afternoon. However, it can tolerate full sun conditions, especially in cooler climates where the added warmth is beneficial. In hotter regions, some afternoon shade will protect the plant from the harshest sun, preventing leaf scorch. Adequate light exposure is crucial for healthy flowering and robust growth, so ensure the plant is not in constant shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iris foetidissima is mainly about removing old or damaged foliage and spent flower stems to maintain its appearance and encourage healthy growth. After flowering, deadhead any spent blooms by cutting the flower stems back to the base to prevent self-seeding. In late autumn or early spring, remove any withered, yellowing, or damaged leaves to tidy up the plant and promote air circulation around the base. It's essential to avoid cutting the central leaves that are still green and healthy, as they are necessary for photosynthesis and the plant's overall vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Stinking iris","description":"Iris foetidissima (Stinking iris, gladdon, Gladwin iris, roast-beef plant, stinking gladwin), is a species of iris found in open woodland, hedgebanks and sea-cliffs.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["Stinking iris"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Iris foetidissima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is moist but not soggy; allow the top inch to dry out between waterings. Over time, reduce frequency, focusing on deep watering during extended periods without rain to maintain health and vitality. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to encourage healthy growth and improve airflow through the canopy. Thinning out dense areas helps reduce the risk of disease and pest infestations. Ensure your pruning tools are sharp and clean to prevent injury and disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black Hawthorn","description":"Crataegus douglasii is a North American species of hawthorn known by the common names black hawthorn and Douglas' thornapple. When watering, ensure the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. During dry spells, water deeply and less frequently to encourage deep root growth. The frequency of watering will depend on the local climate and soil conditions, but providing a deep soak once a week during dry periods is usually sufficient."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laurel oaks thrive best in full sun to partial shade conditions. This species requires a minimum of 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure healthy growth. While it can tolerate some shade, optimal sunlight exposure helps in developing a sturdy trunk and a full, robust canopy. In shaded areas, the tree may grow more slowly and develop a sparser canopy. If planting in a partially shaded location, ensure that it receives morning sunlight if possible, as this will help the tree to establish and maintain its health and vigor effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus laurifolia should be done during its dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring, before new growth starts. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain a strong structure and promote healthy growth. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree; instead, aim for minimal cuts to encourage natural shape and form. If needed, corrective pruning can be done to manage size or to remove lower branches as the tree matures, allowing for clearance under the canopy. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swamp laurel oak","description":"Quercus laurifolia (swamp laurel oak, diamond-leaf oak, water oak, obtusa oak, laurel oak) is a medium-sized semi-evergreen oak in the red oak section Quercus sect. Lobatae. It is native to the southeastern and south-central the United States, from coastal Virginia to central Florida and west to southeast Texas. There are reports of the species growing in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, but these probably represent introductions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["swamp laurel oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Oak wilt","Phytophthora root rot","Anthracnose"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus laurifolia"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It thrives in dry conditions, so it is important to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so during the growing season (spring and summer), water every 2 to 3 weeks. In the fall and winter, reduce the frequency to once a month or less. Always ensure the container has good drainage if potted, and avoid watering from above to prevent water accumulation in the rosette, which can cause rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave deserti thrives in full sun, which means it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. It can tolerate partial shade, but too much shade can lead to elongated or weak growth and reduced vigor. This plant naturally grows in arid, sunny environments, so providing ample sunlight helps maintain its compact form and blue-green coloration. If growing indoors, place it near the brightest window or under a grow light to mimic its natural habitat. Be cautious of sudden changes in light exposure to prevent shock."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agave deserti is generally minimal and involves removing dead or damaged leaves. Use a sharp, clean knife or pruning shears to cut away these leaves close to their base, taking care not to damage the healthy ones. Always wear protective gloves and clothing as the leaf margins may be sharp. Pruning can be done at any time of the year when dead or damaged foliage is observed. Removing the flower stalk after blooming prevents the plant from setting seeds as agaves typically flower once and then die, although offsets may continue growing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"desert agave","description":"Agave deserti (desert agave, mescal, century plant or maguey) is an agave native to desert regions in southern California, Arizona, and Baja California. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to promote optimal blooming. However, in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the foliage from scorching. While the stems and foliage prefer sunlight, the plant's roots benefit from being shaded or mulched to keep them cool and moist. Planting clematis where it can climb up trellises or fences helps ensure it gets ample sunlight for the upper foliage and flowers while the base remains shaded."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis virginiana is essential to encourage healthy growth and is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges. Since this species blooms on new wood, you can trim back old stems to about 12 to 18 inches above the ground, promoting vigorous new shoots. Remove any dead, damaged, or tangled stems at the base, and thin out the plant to improve air circulation. Regular pruning also helps maintain its shape and keeps the vigorous plant manageable, preventing it from overwhelming nearby plants or structures."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"virgin's-bower","description":"Clematis virginiana (also known as devil's darning needles, devil's hair, love vine, traveller's joy, virgin's bower, Virginia virgin's bower, wild hops, and woodbine; syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13929,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cydonia oblonga, commonly known as quince, requires moderate watering. It thrives in well-drained soil, and it's crucial to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, especially in dry conditions, water the quince every week or so to maintain slight soil moisture. However, once established, quince trees are fairly drought-tolerant and may not need frequent watering. In the dormant winter season, reduce watering significantly to prevent excess soil moisture. Always check the top few inches of soil before watering; if it feels dry, then it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cydonia oblonga prefers full sun, which means it needs at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to thrive. Placing it in a location with ample sunlight will promote healthy growth, flowering, and fruiting. While quince trees can tolerate partial shade, this may result in reduced fruit production and slower growth. Therefore, for optimum fruit yield and healthy development, plant your quince in a spot that receives plenty of sun. Ensure that its exposure to direct sunlight is consistent throughout the seasons for the best results in both plant health and fruit quality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cydonia oblonga should ideally be done during late winter when the plant is dormant. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased wood to maintain tree health. Open up the canopy to increase air circulation and sunlight penetration, which helps reduce disease incidence. Remove any crossing branches and suckers that might appear around the base. Aim to shape the tree into an open center or vase shape, which is common for fruit trees, allowing light to reach all parts of the tree. Regular pruning helps maintain a manageable size and improves fruit quality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Quince","description":"The quince (/ˈkwɪns/; Cydonia oblonga) is the sole member of the genus Cydonia in the family Rosaceae (which also contains apples and pears, among other fruits). It is a small deciduous tree that bears a pome fruit, similar in appearance to a pear, and bright golden-yellow when mature. Throughout history the cooked fruit has been used as food, but the tree is also grown for its attractive pale pink blossoms and other ornamental qualities.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southwest Asia","Caucasus region"],"other_name":["Quince"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fire blight","Codling moth","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Cydonia oblonga"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In cooler climates, ensure it gets as much sun as possible during winter months. For indoor growing, place the plant near a south-facing window to maximize its light intake."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Grevillea robusta is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. This encourages air circulation and sunlight penetration to the tree's interior. For young trees, formative pruning helps establish a strong framework. For mature trees, light pruning helps maintain size and encourages a healthy structure. Avoid heavy pruning as it might stress the tree. Always prune back to a lateral branch or bud to ensure smooth healing and regrowth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"silk oak","description":"Grevillea robusta, commonly known as the southern silky oak, silk oak or silky oak, or Australian silver oak, is the largest species in the genus Grevillea of the family Proteaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13238,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leptosyne bigelovii, commonly known as Bigelow's tickseed, typically requires moderate watering. It's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as this plant is adapted to semi-arid conditions. Water deeply but infrequently, ensuring good drainage. During its active growing season in spring and early summer, you can increase watering frequency slightly, but always make sure the soil has excellent drainage to avoid waterlogging. Reduce watering in late summer and fall as the plant becomes more dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leptosyne bigelovii thrives in full sunlight, ideally receiving at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. This plant is well-adapted to sunny, dry environments akin to its native desert habitat, so providing adequate sunlight is crucial for optimal growth and flowering. If growing indoors or in partially shaded areas, ensure it receives as much bright light as possible, possibly by positioning it near a south-facing window or using supplemental grow lights. Insufficient sun can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Leptosyne bigelovii is quite minimal. This plant benefits from occasional deadheading or the removal of spent blooms to encourage continued flowering and tidier appearance. After the flowering season is over, you can cut back any dead or diseased stems to the base. Be cautious not to prune healthy green growth, as this plant prefers to grow naturally without much intervention. In the fall, you can trim back lightly, but avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent damage and disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bigelow's tickseed","description":"Coreopsis bigelovii is a species of flowering plant in the daisy or sunflower family, Asteraceae, with the common names Bigelow coreopsis and Bigelow's tickseed. It is endemic to California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Bigelow's tickseed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Leptosyne bigelovii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12836,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex stipata, commonly known as the awl-fruited sedge, thrives in moist to wet conditions, often found near water bodies. It prefers consistently damp soil, so regular watering is essential, especially in dry periods. Ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. While it tolerates short periods of drought, long dry spells should be avoided to maintain healthy growth. Consider mimicking its natural habitat by providing regular water or planting it in areas where the soil naturally retains moisture, such as near ponds or marshes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex stipata performs best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least four to six hours of sunlight per day, ideally in the morning or late afternoon. However, it can tolerate more shaded conditions, though growth may be less vigorous. Partial shade is suitable, especially in hotter climates, to prevent leaf scorch. When planting, consider an area that gets dappled sunlight or is shielded from the intense midday sun, which replicates its natural environment on the forest floor or shaded wetland edges."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex stipata involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's appearance and health. Typically, a once-a-year pruning in early spring is sufficient, using sharp, clean scissors or shears to trim back the foliage to the base. This promotes new growth and prevents potential diseases. Be mindful not to cut new shoots as this could hinder the plant's growth. Regularly checking and tidying the plant throughout the growing season can also be beneficial to remove any spent flowerheads and maintain its form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"awl-fruited sedge","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["awl-fruited sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Carex stipata"],"soil":["Wet","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12533,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Larix occidentalis, commonly known as the Western larch, requires regular watering during its growing season, especially during dry spells. Young trees need more consistent moisture to establish strong roots. However, this species tolerates occasional dry periods once established, as it typically grows in areas with natural rainfall. Always ensure that the soil drains well to prevent waterlogging since excessive moisture can lead to root rot. During dormancy in the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough to keep the roots slightly moist."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Western larch thrives in full sun, requiring a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight daily. This species is accustomed to the bright, open areas of its native mountainous habitats in North America. Ample sunlight promotes dense foliage and robust growth, as well as enhances its autumn color display. When planting, ensure the site is not overly shaded by larger trees or structures. If grown in partial shade, expect reduced vigor and sparser growth. In hot climates, morning sun with some afternoon shade can help mitigate heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Larix occidentalis is best done during its dormant period in late winter or early spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain tree health and appearance. Pruning promotes air circulation within the crown and helps light penetrate the interior. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree; instead, focus on minor shaping to encourage natural growth form. When pruning, always use sharp, sterilized tools to prevent the spread of diseases, and make clean cuts just outside the branch collar."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"western larch","description":"Larix occidentalis, the western larch, is a species of larch native to the mountains of western North America, in Canada in southeastern British Columbia and southwestern Alberta, and in the United States in eastern Washington, eastern Oregon, northern Idaho, and western Montana.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["western larch"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Larix occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13334,"attracts":["Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mirabilis laevis, commonly known as the desert four o'clock, prefers well-draining soil and is drought-tolerant once established. It should be watered sparingly, particularly in its dormant season during winter. During the growing season in spring and summer, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other diseases, so ensure the plant has sufficient drainage to avoid water stagnation. Adjust the watering schedule based on seasonal rainfall and humidity levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mirabilis laevis thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct light per day to bloom profusely. It can tolerate partial shade, but prolonged exposure to shaded conditions may reduce flowering and cause leggy growth. When planting outdoors, choose a location that receives abundant sunlight throughout the day. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window where it can absorb ample sunlight. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even growth and exposure to light sources."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mirabilis laevis involves removing dead or wilted flowers and leaves to encourage new growth and maintain a neat appearance. This should be done regularly throughout the blooming season. In the late fall or early winter, you can prune more extensively to shape the plant and remove any dead stems. Be cautious not to cut back too severely, as this can stress the plant. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease, and consider wearing gloves, as the plant may cause skin irritation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wishbone Bush","description":"Mirabilis laevis, desert wishbone-bush, is a recently redefined species of flowering plant in the four o'clock family. Distribution is in the Southwestern United States and northwest Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Wishbone Bush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Mirabilis laevis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12635,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave shawii, also known as Shaw's Agave, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. To properly care for this plant, water it deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. This mimics its natural desert environment and prevents root rot, which can occur if the plant is kept too moist. During the growing season, typically in spring and summer, it may require a bit more water but still avoid overwatering. In fall and winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant's growth slows down during these cooler months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave shawii thrives in full sun, which is crucial for its vigorous growth and healthy development. Aim to place the plant in a location where it receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to elongated leaves and a weaker structure. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. If growing indoors, choose the brightest spot available, preferably near a south-facing window, to satisfy its high light requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agave shawii is not typically a frequent necessity, except for removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant’s appearance and health. When pruning, use sharp, clean tools to cut the leaves close to the plant's base, taking care not to damage surrounding healthy leaves. Wear gloves to protect your hands from sharp spines and potentially irritating sap. Pruning is best done in the spring before the plant's active growing period, allowing for easier healing of cuts. Avoid over-pruning, as removing too many leaves can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Shaw's Agave","description":"Agave shawii, with the common names coastal agave or Shaw's agave, is a very rare and critically endangered species in the genus Agave native to southwestern California and Baja California. The plant is named for Henry Shaw, the founder of the Missouri Botanical Garden.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["USA","Mexico"],"other_name":["Shaw's Agave"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Agave shawii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12235,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Blue Palo Verde (Parkinsonia florida) is native to arid desert regions, which means it is highly drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering once established. For young trees, water deeply every couple of weeks during the growing season to encourage deep root growth, but ensure the soil dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. As the tree matures, reduce watering frequency to once a month or less in the absence of rainfall. In winter, watering should be significantly reduced or stopped altogether, as the tree is dormant during this time."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parkinsonia florida thrives in full sun conditions and should receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. Being a desert-native species, it is adapted to withstand intense sunlight and performs best in environments with abundant light. When planting, choose a location that is unobstructed by structures or larger trees that may cast shade. This plant's ability to capture and utilize sunlight efficiently helps it flourish in arid environments and contributes to its striking golden bloom display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Parkinsonia florida should generally occur in late fall or early winter after the tree has finished blooming. The primary goal is to remove dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain the tree’s structure and health. Additionally, thinning the canopy can improve airflow and sunlight penetration. When pruning, make clean cuts at a branch collar and avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the tree. Regular pruning will help maintain a balanced shape, promote robust health, and encourage flowering in the following growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"blue palo verde","description":"Parkinsonia florida, the blue palo verde (syn. Cercidium floridum), is a species of palo verde native to the Sonoran Deserts in the Southwestern United States and Northwestern Mexico. Its name means \"green pole or stick\" in Spanish, referring to the green trunk and branches, that perform photosynthesis.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["blue palo verde"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Parkinsonia florida"],"soil":["Sand","Loam"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important not to let the soil dry out completely, as this can stress the plant. A general rule is to keep the soil damp, but not waterlogged. In indoor settings, watering should be adjusted based on the ambient humidity and soil moisture levels. During hotter periods, it may require more frequent watering. It's crucial to ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot, despite the plant's love for moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acorus calamus thrives in full to partial sunlight. Ideally, it should receive about 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive heat. If grown indoors, placing it near a bright window can suffice. However, avoid exposing the plant to intense midday sun through glass, which can cause leaf scorch. Generally, this plant is quite adaptable but flourishes best with ample light to maintain its vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acorus calamus involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to maintain its appearance and encourage healthy growth. This can be done throughout the growing season. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to cut the leaves at their base. Pruning can also help control the size and spread of the plant, especially if it is grown in a confined space like a container."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Eurasian Sweet-Flag","description":"Acorus calamus (also called sweet flag or calamus, among many common names) is a tall perennial wetland monocot of the Acoraceae family, in the genus Acorus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Eurasian Sweet-Flag"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Acorus calamus"],"soil":["Wet","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14023,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vaccinium pallidum, commonly known as the lowbush blueberry, prefers slightly moist soil but is also drought-tolerant. It is crucial not to overwater, as these plants do not like to have their roots constantly wet. Generally, watering once a week is sufficient, depending on the climate and soil conditions, ensuring the topsoil has dried out between waterings. In hotter, drier seasons, you may need to increase the frequency slightly. Be sure to water at the base of the plant to keep the leaves dry and reduce the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vaccinium pallidum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. While it can tolerate some shade, for optimal growth and fruit production, ensure the plant receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In areas with intense afternoon sunshine, providing some light shade can prevent leaf scorch. However, too much shade may result in reduced flowering and fewer berries, so find a balance that provides adequate light while protecting the plant from extreme conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vaccinium pallidum is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to keep the plant healthy. Additionally, trim back any overly long shoots to maintain a compact shape and encourage bushier growth, which can enhance berry production. Pruning should be done lightly to avoid stressing the plant, as too much pruning can reduce the following season’s yield. It's generally a low-maintenance plant, so heavy pruning is not necessary. Trim back the stems in early spring before the active growing season to shape the plant and remove any unsightly growth. You can also pinch back tips to encourage bushier growth if necessary. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease. Regular observation will help to maintain the plant’s aesthetic and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sharp-leaved Fluellen","description":"Kickxia elatine is a species of flowering plant in the Plantaginaceae known by several common names, including sharpleaf cancerwort and sharp-leaved fluellen. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13135,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Grindelia squarrosa, commonly known as curlycup gumweed, is a drought-tolerant plant that doesn't require frequent watering. It thrives in well-drained soil and can withstand dry conditions once established. During the initial growing season, water regularly to help the plant establish a robust root system. After establishment, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot, especially in heavy soils. In periods of extended drought, occasional watering can keep the plant looking its best, but it's generally resilient in dry conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Grindelia squarrosa thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. It is a sun-loving plant, well-suited for open, sunny sites and performs poorly in shaded areas. Full sun exposure encourages vigorous growth and a robust blooming cycle, while partial shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If growing in a region with intense afternoon sun, the plant can tolerate it well. Ensure to position it in areas that mimic its natural, sun-drenched habitats for the best development and highest ornamental value."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a necessary routine for Grindelia squarrosa, but it can be beneficial to promote a more compact shape and remove any dead or diseased growth. Light pruning in the spring can encourage bushier growth by trimming back overgrown stems. After the flowering season, deadhead spent flowers to prevent self-seeding if you don't want the plant to spread, as well as to improve its appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts just above a healthy bud or branch. Regularly inspect for pests and diseases and remove any affected parts promptly to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Curlycup Gumweed","description":"Grindelia squarrosa, also known as a curly-top gumweed or curlycup gumweed, is a small North American biennial or short-lived perennial plant.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Curlycup Gumweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Grindelia squarrosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If flowering is a priority, prune after the plant has bloomed to avoid cutting off buds."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mediterranean buckthorn","description":"Rhamnus alaternus is a species of flowering plant in the buckthorn family Rhamnaceae, known by the common names Italian buckthorn or Mediterranean buckthorn. It's important to also remove any suckers or shoots that grow from the base of the tree, as these can divert energy from the main stem and reduce fruit production. It is important not to let the soil dry out completely between waterings, as this species thrives in wet environments such as marshlands or near streams. Ensure the plant has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which could harm its roots. Water thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry, particularly in hotter weather, and reduce watering frequency in the winter when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphyotrichum puniceum thrives best in full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing the plant with some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. When planted in partial shade, make sure the location receives ample indirect light to support robust growth and flowering. These conditions mimic their natural habitats, which are often open wetlands or along sunny stream banks."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning purple-stemmed asters is essential to maintain healthy growth and encourage blooming. In early spring, remove dead or damaged stems to allow new growth. As the plant grows, pinching back the stems in early summer can promote bushier growth and more flowers. After the blooming period, you can deadhead the spent flowers to prevent self-seeding if you don't want the plant to spread. Shear the plant back after flowering or in late fall to tidy up the garden and prepare the plant for winter dormancy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"swamp aster","description":"Symphyotrichum puniceum (formerly Aster puniceus), commonly known as purplestem aster, red-stalk aster, red-stemmed aster or swamp aster, is an herbaceous perennial native to eastern North America. Observing the plant's response will guide whether more or less sunlight is needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Persicaria hydropiper should focus on maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, more significant pruning might be required to reshape it. Additionally, removing spent flowers can help prolong blooming. Pruning is ideally done in spring or late summer, which can also help prevent the plant from becoming invasive, as it can spread quite rapidly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"waterpepper","description":"Water-pepper, water pepper or marshpepper knotweed (Persicaria hydropiper, syn. In regions with regular rainfall, natural precipitation may provide adequate moisture, but be mindful to adjust watering during dry and hot weather to compensate for lack of rain."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silene latifolia thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It is also known in the US as bladder campion but should not be confused with Silene vulgaris, which is more generally called bladder campion.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["white campion"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Silene latifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to improve air circulation and prevent fungal infections, but avoid extensive cutting as it might stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woodcock orchid","description":"Ophrys scolopax, known as the woodcock bee-orchid or woodcock orchid, is a species of terrestrial orchid found around the Mediterranean and the Middle East, from Morocco and Portugal to Hungary and Iran.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["woodcock orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Ophrys scolopax"],"soil":["Well-drained","Calcareous"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the flowering season, lightly trim the plant to remove spent flowers and any untidy growth. Don't cut back into the old wood as it may not regenerate. Instead, focus on shaping and encouraging the plant to bush out. If the plant becomes too leggy, a slightly harder prune in early spring can stimulate more robust growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Rock-rose","description":"Helianthemum nummularium (known as common rock-rose) is a species of rock-rose (Cistaceae), native to most of Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Common Rock-rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Helianthemum nummularium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent root rot. During the active growing season, water it regularly, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. In the dormant winter months, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant requires less moisture and is susceptible to overwatering during this time."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ageratina occidentalis thrives best in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure helps promote more vigorous flowering and a healthier plant overall."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ageratina occidentalis is typically carried out in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Pruning helps in shaping the plant and encourages denser growth. Avoid excessive pruning, which can stress the plant; instead, focus on removing no more than one-third of the plant at a time to ensure its vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Snakeroot","description":"Ageratina occidentalis is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family known by the common name western snakeroot or western eupatorium. It is native to the western United States where it grows in several types of habitat. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13732,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Utricularia subulata is a carnivorous plant that thrives in moist conditions. To ensure it remains healthy, maintain consistently wet soil. It prefers distilled or rainwater, as tap water can contain minerals and chemicals that may be harmful. The soil should never be allowed to dry out completely, as this can stress the plant. A common watering method is the tray method, where a shallow tray beneath the pot is kept filled with water. This ensures the soil stays moist from the bottom up without constantly dumping water from the top."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Utricularia subulata prefers bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the morning or late afternoon, but prolonged exposure to strong midday sun can scorch its delicate leaves. Providing about 4-6 hours of indirect sunlight is ideal for promoting healthy growth. If grown indoors, a bright windowsill where it is protected from the harshest sun is ideal. In its natural habitat, it often grows under filtered light conditions, such as below taller vegetation or in marshy areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Utricularia subulata is generally minimal but can be beneficial to encourage healthy growth and prevent the spread of any potential disease. Regularly remove dead or dying leaves to keep the plant tidy and to prevent mold or rot. If the plant produces an abundance of flowers, you may also trim these back after they fade to encourage more compact foliage growth. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent tearing the plant tissue or introducing pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Zigzag Bladderwort","description":"Utricularia subulata, the zigzag bladderwort, is a small annual, terrestrial carnivorous plant that belongs to the genus Utricularia (family Lentibulariaceae). It is the most widely distributed species in the genus, being almost pantropical.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","South America"],"other_name":["Zigzag Bladderwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Utricularia subulata"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13633,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Simmondsia chinensis, commonly known as jojoba, is a drought-resistant shrub and requires minimal watering once established. During the first year after planting, water the shrub every two weeks to help it develop a strong root system. After it is established, water only once a month or during prolonged dry spells to prevent overwatering. Jojoba prefers well-drained soil, and allowing the top layer to dry completely between waterings is important to prevent root rot. In humid climates, reduce watering frequency further, as jojoba is adapted to arid environments and does not thrive in persistently wet conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Simmondsia chinensis thrives in full sun conditions and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. It is well-suited to hot, dry climates and can withstand high temperatures, making it ideal for desert-like environments. Jojoba can tolerate partial shade, but too much shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering and fruit production. When planting jojoba, choose a location that guarantees plenty of sunlight exposure throughout the day to ensure healthy development and robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning jojoba (Simmondsia chinensis) is not a frequent requirement, as it naturally maintains a tidy shape. However, light pruning can be done annually or biennially to remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches that may hinder growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant. Pruning can also be used to promote bushier growth by trimming back the tips of branches. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts and minimize damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"jojoba","description":"Jojoba /həˈhoʊbə/ ( listen), with the botanical name Simmondsia chinensis, and also known as goat nut, deer nut, pignut, wild hazel, quinine nut, coffeeberry, and gray box bush, is native to Southwestern North America. Simmondsia chinensis is the sole species of the family Simmondsiaceae, placed in the order Caryophyllales.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Northern Mexico"],"other_name":["jojoba"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Simmondsia chinensis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12838,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex vesicaria, commonly known as blister sedge, prefers consistently moist to wet soil conditions, making it suitable for rain gardens, ponds, or wetland areas. Water this plant regularly to maintain soil moisture, especially during dry spells. It's tolerant of temporary flooding or standing water but should not be allowed to dry out completely. In container settings, ensure good drainage but keep the soil damp by watering frequently, aiming for a soil consistency that's moist but not waterlogged."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Blister sedge thrives best under full sun to partial shade conditions. It is adaptable to a range of sunlight exposures, but it will grow more vigorously and produce more abundant foliage and flowers if it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching. However, it's quite adaptable and can also grow in partially shaded conditions, though this might result in slightly reduced growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex vesicaria involves cutting back the dead or damaged foliage to maintain its appearance and encourage new growth. This should typically be done in late fall after the plant has finished its growing season or in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp shears to trim the leaves down to about 2-3 inches above the base. Removing spent flower stalks can be done throughout the growing season to keep the plant tidy. Avoid excessive cutting, as it can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"inflated sedge","description":"Carex vesicaria is an essentially Holarctic species of sedge known by the common names bladder-sedge, blister sedge. The dried fibers, sometimes used as thermal insulation in polar regions, are known as sennegrass, saennegrass or similar, from the plant's Bokmål name sennegras.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["inflated sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Carex vesicaria"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
